text:
I made this recipe this weekend and didn't care too much for it. I was so excited for it and was pretty disappointed. It the flavor was good but the recipe needs quite a bit of work. If I make this again, I will use unite a bit less eggs and blend the cream cheese before adding it to the bread. It was too eggy for my taste and the cream cheese didn't melt sufficiently ( it stayed in chunks and didn't melt enough to blend into the casserole. Also, because the recipe called for so many eggs, it took much longer to bake than the 30 minutes stated in the recipe (I ended up baking it for an additional 45 minutes). The blueberry sauce was the best part but next time I will probably let people pour it on individually rather than onto the entire casserole as stated in the recipe. I would probably also use half the amount of cream cheese as well. Overall, I was quite dissapointed in this recipe and believe it can be made better

text:
Excellent.  But, I did whip the cream cheese with a 1/3 cup of icing sugar and spread over the bread.  Also, I used Ciabata bread - because nice and dense. I brought this to a pot luck brunch and it was probably the favourite dish and everyone wanted the recipe.  YUUMMMMMMM

text:
Agree with fellow posters that the bread should be a nice French bread. Remember, the cream cheese is cubed, not spread. I only used one and one half pkgs of cream cheese and that was perfect. I also added another cup of loose blueberries to the  bread part.  I found it needed to baker little longer; just keep an eye on it, watching for the center to set and the bread to brown nicely on the top.  If you are lucky enough to have leftovers it warms up nicely too. This is a new keeper for holidays at my house!

text:
One tip:  When refrigerating an egg casserole overnight, cover the pan with plastic wrap, then place something flat, rigid, and just barely smaller than the pan on top, and weight it down with cans to push the top layer of bread down into the liquid.  That helps the top layer get really soaked.  I followed some of the suggestions in the reviews (10 eggs, more blueberries, spread cream cheese on slices of bread) and this turned out great!  Our family enjoyed it for breakfast, and when playdate friends stayed over into lunchtime the leftovers got rave reviews.

text:
OMG this was delicious!  Made this for breakfast on Xmas morning.  Made some slight changes based on others feedback.  Used Italian bread for this.  Softened 1 bar of cream cheese in the micro and mixed with 1/4c of powdered sugar, vanilla extract, cinnamon, nutmeg, & cloves and spread on first layer of bread.  Will up the cream cheese next time!  Used 1-1/2c frozen blueberries and topped with rest of bread.  Used 10 eggs and added 1/2c white sugar instead of the syrup.  Added some extra cinnamon and nutmeg to the mix.  Let sit overnight and popped in the oven for about 1 hour and 15mins at 350.  Didn't have time to let it come to room temp before baking so added a few mins to overall cooking time to make sure it was cooked all the way.  For the syrup, used 1-1/2 c frozen blueberries and lemon zest and juice from 1 lemon.  Add lemon to this it made such a difference! also added a splash of vanilla extract.  My hubby who isn't fond of sweets went back for seconds.  Its warm and gooey and very comforting.  Will definitely make again.  Maybe try cherries next time. YUMMY!

text:
I mostly followed the script but per some of the reviews I read modified a few things. I used a French Baguette for the bread. I used a can of blueberry pie filling instead of making a blueberry syrup and added this to the middle layer. My own twist was I used mascarpone cheese instead of cream cheese. I scattered 8 oz of the cheese with a spoon. To the egg mixture with 10 eggs & I added cinnamon. I also added a sprinkle of cinnamon on top and added some lemon zest to the blueberry pie/fresh blueberry mixture. I put the casserole in the fridge overnight, pulled it out about 45 minutes ahead of baking it. I flipped the entire casserole over prior to baking per a review and this seemed to help in the cooking process so everything was mixed up well and not too soggy. I sprinkled a little brown sugar on top prior to baking for grins. It turned out great!!!! I simply served it with some maple syrup. I will definitely make this again. Thanks for sharing the recipe! Happy Holidays!

text:
I have been saving this recipe for a Christmas holiday opportunity.  I forgot to start it the night before but decided to go with it anyway.  I read through reviews to see if anyone else had done this, but didn't find any reference, it would be nice to have a search function on the reviews. I went boldly ahead, and used homemade bread that was a couple days old, a good solid bread.  I spread the cream cheese on the bread and cut it up.   I used twice the amount of blueberries and then added the mixture of egg milk vanilla over the top.  Because I wasn't going to store in the fridge, I left it out on the counter for about 45 min or an hour with a plate over it and my teapot on top to weigh it down and force the bread to be more smooshed into the egg mixture.  it looked like the egg was pretty well absorbed, and it baked up well.  Since I used frozen blueberries I baked it 40 minutes then another 40 with the cover off.  I made the sauce per instruction, and it all came out great.  I will definitely try this again.

text:
Great recipe!!  Changed eggs to 10 and increased blueberry to 2 cups. I decreased cream cheese to 1brick and added 1 cup of milk to it and blended it slowly in microwave mixing ever 15 seconds until nearly smooth.  Do not scald milk!!  Don't worry if small lumps still exist.  Cooked on the second day at 325 for 30 minutes covered and 30 minutes uncovered.  Brought it out and let it rest for 15 minutes. Wonderful!!  Gave it 5 stars anyway because this recipe is very easy and forgiving!!!!

I had been blueberry picking the weekend before a girls weekend at my sister-in-laws and decided to try this since I was in charge of breakfast.  Everyone went crazy over it, it reheated well for breakfast on the 2nd day and all the girls talked about how delicious it was all day and could not wait for breakfast the next day.

Only tip I have is I did not buy my bread a day before cutting in up and it was hard to cut since it was too soft so make sure you have 1-2 day old bread or it takes a lot of time to dice it up and it smooshes instead of cuts up nice.

text:
This was pretty good with some of the modifications other reviewers suggested. I halved this recipe, but kept the blueberries the same. I used most of a block of light cream cheese, but instead of cubing it, I mixed it with a couple of tablespoons of confectioner's sugar and some almond milk - just enough to thin it out a bit. (I mixed until the consistency looked kind of like large-curd cottage cheese, and it spread over the bread layer just fine.) However, I think the recipe would have been better with even less cream cheese and more fruit. I used about half a loaf (6 oz) of bakery ciabatta bread that I had dried briefly in the oven. It was pretty good but the top layer of bread did not soak up enough of the egg mixture overnight -- and as a result the top layer of bread was pretty dry. I skipped the sauce -- because I was feeling lazy -- but next time I will definitely make the sauce and I think it will help with the dry bread problem.

userID:
6564378
Display Name:
Vicki5280
isPro:

22

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the recipe according to the recipe (with the exception of the maple syrup - didn't have any) and had the same "ehhh" experience that other people have had. I did use Italian bread both times and appreciate the density and and crust:bread ratio in the italian vs other breads I was able to find.  Sandwich breads are already sliced too thin, so I wouldn't suggest even attempting to use them with this recipe. Otherwise, I see no need to be repeatedly redundant when it's already been said so well by others.  I tried it again with some of the suggested modifications - that review is totally different!

The second time, to begin, I used 10 eggs and added "some" fresh nutmeg and cinnamon.  Secondly, I whipped two cubes of room temp cream cheese with powdered sugar (to taste) and smeared that ON TOP of the blueberries.  Spreading the cream cheese mixture on the blueberries was far easier than spreading directly onto the bread.  As suggested by someone else, I was sure to "mash" everything down into the egg mixture with it was all assembled to make sure that all the bread was soaked.  Because I'm in Denver, I had to bake mine quite a while extra, but it was worth the wait!  I doubled the syrup recipe and EVERYONE was glad I had.  The second batch was a hit from start to finish. 

Looking back, I think next time, I'll cut back some on the amount of milk that goes into the egg mixture because I felt the middle was still a little bit "squishier" than I wanted it to be.
Review:

5

I followed some of the suggestions, and mixed the softened (light) cream cheese with a bit of the milk and a little sugar, then dolloped the creamy mixture over the first layer. This is a "having company" keeper!

text:
This recipe was a huge success at Mother's day brunch today! It will now be a regular at my brunches. I read the other reviews a bit too late and had already purchased plain white sandwich bread and used all 12 eggs but thank goodness I could see the bread was not gonna hold up, so I toasted it very lightly just to make it a little more dry and crusty, more like day old bread. Then I used a few more slices than called for to make sure I soaked up all the egg. I did notice I had to cook it longer to make sure all the egg was cooked and the middle was firm probably even 15 min longer. If you or your guests love blueberry pie, pancakes or cheesecake you will love, love, love this. PS fresh homeade whipped cream on the side for guests to spoon on is a must.

text:
Great recipe.  Lots of compliments and requests for recipe.  Stuck to the recipe for the most part.  Took the suggestions of some reviewers and used French bread, used low fat cream cheese, whipped the cream cheese when soft with some powdered sugar & a little milk (tho this isn't necessary) and doubled the sauce.  Tho some used less cream cheese, I did not.  I liked the gooier parts with the crusty parts.  I did not put the sauce on afterwards--I served in a bowl so people could add their own sauce, or use maple syrup as an alternative.  I used both! Next time I will make a lighter version (i never use lighter versions of anything new when serving to company b/c you never know how it will turn out) and try cranberries or other fruit.  Yum!

text:
This recipe is so easy and the results are outstanding.  Every time I have made this for a breakfast potluck it has been the hit of the morning.  For an interesting twist, I once threw in some raspberries and blackberries as well.  It came out very nicely!  

One thing I do a little differently is whip the cream cheese with a little confectioners sugar and spread it over the bread.  It just makes for a little nicer consistency and flavor, but the original recipe has always been a big hit whenever I make it.  I also like to experiment with different kinds of bread.

text:
I cannot WAIT to make this again. I accidentally left it in the oven for an hour and 20 minutes so the top bread was too crispy but the underneath part was soooooooo yummy.  So in addition to not burning the casserole, next time I will put more blueberries inside on the 1st layer and I will use a different sauce; this one was bizarre. "Blueberry Breakfast Sauce" from this site is much better, there's less sugar and water and more blueberries. Thanks to others for the suggestion of whipping the cream cheese with milk so it could pour onto the bread instead of placing chunks that don't melt everywhere. I only used 1 block of cream cheese since I'm not a huge fan and I didn't want it to overwhelm the flavors. I used challah bread and it worked great.  FYI it's really good cold too!

As is I give this recipe a 4 star rating, even though my husband doesnt like french toast and he raved about this.  For me, it just lacked something.  Here is what I did to make it a 5 star recipe...I only used 1 8oz block of cream cheese and sprinkled  cinnamin/sugar on top of the top layer of bread cubes.  Then for the egg mixture, I used the eggs as called for and instead of milk, I used 2 cups of vanilla flavored liq coffee creamer and omitted the vanilla extract.  I  also increased the maple syrup in the mixture to about 1/2 cup.

text:
Oh man! So yummy! I used blackberries instead of blueberries and it is to DIE for. More like dessert then breakfast, like a blackberry, cream cheese bread pudding. I whipped the cream cheese with a small amount of sugar and milk and put it in a bag and squirted it over the bread. When I made the syrup I mashed the blackberries with a potato masher to infuse the flavor throughout. Can't wait to try this with other fruit. Delish!

I made this for my mom and grandmother for Mother's Day and it was a great success!  I used some of the suggestions from other reviewers such as adding powdered sugar to the cream cheese and mixing.  I loved that I could make it the night before and just stick it in the oven the next morning. This is also a great left over dish for breakfast the remainder of the week or even dessert!

Tiel Mom
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
540
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this today for dinner to test recipe before serving to guests next week and it was scrumptious!  The top and bottom were crispy and and it tasted like french toast/blueberry pancakes.  I followed advice given in reviews, used a whole loaf of french bread and 3 extra thick slices of homemade white bread to fill the top layer. Only used  1 package of cream cheese mixed with 1/4 cup of powder sugar, a few drops of vanilla and a dash of cinnamon. Used 2 cups of frozen blueberries from last Summer, not thawed. Instead of maple syrup, I used 1/3 cup sugar,  a dash of salt and sprinkled cinnamon on top before refrigerating. I only had time to refrigerate for 5 hours. Sprinkled some white sugar on top layer of bread cubes right before baking. It baked up in 1 hour. All of the liquid was absorbed--not soggy or gooey at all. It was served with warm maple syrup  to save time today. (made that before and it's a 10 star)Just perfect! Will definitely make this again and with other fruits as well.
Review:

text:
I made this recipe for Easter brunch.  It turned out fantastic!  I did take the advice of some of the reviews and added a little milk and powedered sugar to the cream cheese and whipped it up.  This made it easier to spread and a more even dispersion of the cream cheese across the bake. I used frozen blueberries and that worked out fine. I also added chopped walnuts and sprinkled on top.  Added a little bit of cinnamon and nutmeg....yummy   It is a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to be sure this would be delicious for my husband's birthday breakfast so I read many of the reviews. I used 10 eggs and 1.5 packages of cream cheese and I also chose to use a long French baguette, cut into 1" pieces (smaller actually). I wanted to avoid what some reviewers said was a strange reaction to the cream cheese chunks. So I tried to make the "chunks" very small and spread them around on all the pieces of bread by hand (icky!). I also didn't make the syrup and we just used maple syrup. The end result? Everything "worked" but it didn't have much of a taste, which was disappointing. It also was quite "eggy" and could have used 1-2 less eggs (8 total). I don't know what else would improve it - perhaps sprinkling some sugar on the whole thing to add more taste. Perhaps simply the blueberry syrup would have been better. Either way, I don't know if this is the best thing to make for a special occasion (at least test it out another day first).

text:
I made this for an Easter brunch and it was very well-received.  Beautiful and delicious.  I used two French bagettes cut in 1" slices and dried in my oven for an hour at 200, then quartered each slice after spreading with cream cheese.  I used a big 9x13 stoneware dish and followed some of the reviewer's advice by cutting the eggs to 10 and cutting the cream cheese to one package - wish I hadn't done it.  My great big dish could have handled the extras and there wasn't tons of cream cheese flavor, but everyone still loved it.  I served the blueberry compote on the side and let guests ladle what they wanted on top of their serving.  This was THE hit at our Easter brunch and I'm glad I was the one who brought it!  Thanks for sharing the recipe!

This is a very flexible receipe. I make multiple substitutions and it's great. I substitute egg substitute for the eggs, non-fat milk for whole milk, fat-free cream cheese for regular cream cheese, and Splenda for sugar, maple flavor for syrup, and lower calorie bread. I usually add cinnamon or cardamom to the egg mixture, too.

We absolutely loved everything about this! It was very easy to put together. Changes I made include: used a French loaf and layered the bottom of the pan with slices covered with the cream cheese, then cubed the rest of the loaf and more cream cheese cubed up. Doubled the amount of blueberries....(we love blueberries). Also added a little cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice and a tiny bit of cloves. Lastly, had to add the whipped cream in lieu of more syrup.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As many other reviewers have said, this is a good start for a terrific recipe. I started with an entire loaf of sliced brioche (13 slices plus both heels). Sprinkled each layer of cubes with 1/4 t cinnamon. Stayed with the 2 blocks of cream cheese but creamed in 1/3 c of powdered sugar. Distributed little dallops across *2* casserole dishes. Doubled fresh berries in the casserole to 2 cups. Used evaporated milk because I had it on hand (1 can plus water to make 2 cups). Stayed with the dozen eggs. Proportions seemed perfect across 2 dishes and made 12 servings. Baking time and temp was just right. Syrup was a must for me to balance the dry bits on top. Loved this!

userID:
26740331
Display Name:
Wontusemyname Really
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7503806.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this in a 10x15 pan, so my quantities of ingredients used reflects that. Like a lot of people, I used Italian bread (about 1-1/2 loaves) and frozen blueberries.  I used 14 eggs and kept the milk the same. I didn't pay any attention to the amount of blueberries, just used what looked right to me (large bag of frozen blueberries from Costco made it so I didn't have to worry about how many I used) As one suggested, I put the cream cheese in the freezer just long enough to firm it up so I could grate it with a cheese grater and used 1-1/2 blocks of cream cheese I didn't want large pockets of the cheese I because I thought it would be too much.  Grating  the cheese was definitely the way to go. I made a double batch of the sauce but could have got by with one.  I put some blueberries sparingly on top.  After it came out of the oven, I drizzled a little of the sauce on top and put the rest on the table.  Lightly dusted the top with powdered sugar, more for decoration than anything else.  I was really pleased with the results.  Making a new recipe for Christmas breakfast with family over is always a little stressful.  Everyone liked it, even my wife, who was sceptical at the get go because she thought the cream cheese was going to be too rich.

text:
I made this yesterday into today. I followed the directions, BUT took other "chefs" advice as well as my own. I used a Hawaiian bread loaf, I cut it thick then cubed it, I used 11 eggs, and I whipped my cream cheese with 1/4 cup powdered sugar. It Is Fantastic! The syrup is delicious, casserole can be eaten with or without. Family loved it too, light souffle like texture, with a hint of sweet with this bread and the cream cheese mixture, which IS lacking in original recipe. Highly Recommend with these changes.

userID:
11775401
Display Name:
Katy G
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7191093.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time I made it exactly as recipe states and I give it four stars. I personally didnt like the cubed chunks of cream cheese, but like everything else. 
However this wouldnt be an Allrecipes review if I didnt add my own spin that makes it my kind of delicious. 
I used the cheap 30 cent walmart french bread loaf that's about to expire. The dryness of the bread and lack of good crust which would normally be lackluster, goes great with French toast because it really soaks everything up. 
What I did was cut it into 1 inch bread slices, slathered it with blueberry flavored spreadable cream cheese (usually for bagels) between each layer and with sections about 4-5 sliced high, cut once longwise, and 4 the other way, giving a bunch of cubes with cream cheese on both sides. I then used clean hands to mix in the berries and separate the pieces. 
I use 10 eggs, 1/4 cup real maple syrup, the vanilla, and 1 1/2 cup milk, with an additional 1/4 tsp cinnamon, for the liquid, poured over and fridged overnight  and baked like normal.
The original topping is delicious, but an easier way is to use a couple tablespoons of the leftover blueberry cream cheese, room temp, and blend it slowly with cream (or plain coffee creamer), then add in powdered sugar to get an easy icing to pour over the while thing.

3

text:
I followed the suggestions of other  people and it turned out great! First of all I only used 9 eggs. I used italian bread as well. I also used one brick of cream cheese and whipped it with 1 tsp of vanilla, 1/4 cup of powdered sugar, and 1/4 cup of whole milk. When I say whipped I ax5uslly used a magic bullet because my mixer broke but it worked just as well! I also replaced the blueberries with just over 1 cup of diced fresh strawberries. At the end I poured half of the egg mixture on top, sprinkled on a generous amount of cinnamon, and then poured the rest on. I put it in for maybe 5-10 minutes extra and it turned out PERFECT.

text:
Made it with fresh peaches instead of blueberries, and it was yummy.  Used King's Hawaiian rolls, lightly toasted in the oven, as the bread.  It took longer than an hour to set the eggs.  For the sauce,  I used only 1/3 c (brown) sugar, no water, and 1 tsp corn starch.  Added a little ginger, lemon juice, and almond extract, then finished it with a pat of butter.    I hate it when people rewrite a recipe before eating; but this is a great basic recipe, and I used what I had on hand. I should have cut the cream cheese into much smaller pieces, but it still tasted great.

text:
I have made this for several family brunches and it's always a favorite. After looking at the review comments, I also made some changes. I beat the cream cheese with some powdered sugar then spread it on the first layer of bread cubes. I prefer this to cubes of cream cheese since it is distributed through out the casserole better. I also use fewer eggs (10 instead of 12).  Sprinkling cinnamon on each layer of bread cubes also adds a very nice flavor.

Delicious and easy for kids to help make too! I used leftover cream cheese icing (because I used the last of my cream cheese up to make icing for an earlier dish), it was so good... No extra blueberry sauce needed on the top because it was sweet enough. I also used only 12 egg yokes because I used 12 egg whites for angel food cake (angel food cake III). Pair these two recipes together and you'll get dessert and breakfast out of the same 12 eggs!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've decided to make a dish and then comment. After reading a few other reviews by others and implementing some of their suggestions, I have no complaints. I used a whole boule instead of sliced bread. It was still a bit soft and not exlpired. So I toasted the bottom layer, until a golden brown, to give it more body and flavor. Excellent choice, even if I do say so myself. It absolutely filled up the entire bottom of the 9x13 in. pan. I put more blueberries in than the recipe called for and sprinkled cinnamon on that layer as well. After putting everything into the pan except the blueberry topping I drizzled a few tablespoons of ghee over the top add another layer of taste and unctuousness (is that a word?) to the final product. And brightened the blueberry topping up with about a quarter of a cup of Meyer lemon juice (it was a double batch, as per another suggestion). Out of the fridge today and into the oven. Couldn't wait for it to cool down. Yummers! Quite a bit left. Come on by and bring a bowl.

text:
This version just didn't do it for us.  I used twice as many blueberries (which our family loves) and half as much cream cheese (which doesn't like our family), but otherwise left everything the same.  I don't much care for overly sweet breakfast good, but we though this could have really used some sugar or more maple syrup in the custard.  The blueberry sauce just seemed flat to use maybe some lemon juice and zest or some ginger to wake it up a bit.  We also found it needed a good half an hour longer to bake.

text:
OUTSTANDING! I made this for Christmas Day breakie...an absolute hit!! I took the advise of other reviewers; used French Brioche bread & 4 bakery croissants instead of regular sliced bread / used frozen blueberries thawed in cold water / broke out my Kitchen Aid mixer and whipped 1 block of cream cheese & sugar and added lime juice (about 2 Tblspns). Using a rubber spatula...very easy to spread evenly. Followed the rest of the recipe to a T. I did not make the sauce, not needed in our household. Its perfectly sweet without. So so soooo good!

text:
Scouring the Allrecipes community for Christmas morning wow factor sweet offerings, I came upon this.  Despite the photos and method that clearly shouted THIS IS. REALLY NOT FRENCH TOAST I forged ahead.  Allow me to underscore.  This is NOT French toast, it‚Äôs bread pudding.  Nomenclature not withstanding,  I must admit, I will try this again with a few modifications:  add more maple syrup or brown sugar  to the liquid portion to sweeten it up.  The blueberry sauce was lovely... just too thick.  Less cornstarch I think, and/or more water. A bowl of whipped cream should DEFINITELY be served alongside this dish. When I finally busted out a can of emergency whipped cream it was met with oohs and ahhs.

text:
Very good! I am not a cook....nor a baker. I hardly ever cook, so I was a little worried about how this would turn out. But I wanted to do something special for my husband for Christmas breakfast. A great way to save time Christmas day...95% of the dish is prepared the night before, and all you need do is make a very simple sauce. 

I read a lot of the reviews, and was grateful for the fact that many more seasoned cooks than I posted about recipe modifications.  I too used less cream cheese. I also used frozen Blueberries,  which in my opinion worked just fine. 

My husband had three very large squares of this...I had two. It is a delicious treat for a special occasion. 

I will be making this again.

text:
Everyone loved it. I made it per the recipe, but when I checked the top layer prior to baking, I found the bread rather dry. I removed the top layer, beat up a few eggs in a bowl (with a little syrup and milk), and soaked the bread for a few minutes. Then proceeded per recipe. I think I would have been disappointed if I hadn't done this. But it is a keeper.

text:
This is a great recipe. I have made it two different ways. Both ways were a hit!!  The first time I made it as the recipe calls for, except I took the tip of whipping the cream cheese. I changed it the 2nd time by whipping 2 of the eggs into the cream cheese, so much easier to spread. Next, used 2 apples chopped up, tossing them with a little brown sugar, cinnamon and a splash of vanilla.  I may use 3 apples next time.  After putting the egg/milk mixture over the bread I sprinkled the top with cinnamon. Then followed directions.  My son loved it on Christmas morning!!  He said that it really tasted like French toast.  Topped it with syrup and a little whip cream. Baked it about a total of 65 minutes.

text:
Delicious!  We will make this again!
I halved all the ingredients except for the blueberries and made it in an oval, 1 1/2 quart casserole dish.  I only had to cut about 5 minutes off the "uncovered" baking time.
Also, I left the butter out of the sauce since I felt like it didn't need it, but I did add a splash of orange juice at the end of cooking the sauce.  I generally feel like blueberry sauce benefits from a splash of citrus at the end.

This was fantastic and easy - made with blueberries and put  a pint in the bread mix and a pint for the sauce.  I used Italian bread and didn't make any changes.  Made for a cabin weekend with a large group and everyone loved it!  Would definitely be delicious with any type of berry.

As a shortcut, we ended up spreading the cream cheese between slices of bread, then slicing the bread and putting in to the 9x13 casserole dish - this seemed to distribute it more evenly than trying to drop chunks of it in to the bread mix.  :)

To the apple recipe I add cinnamon and nutmeg.

Directions incorrect on cook time. Baked 30 min covered and then 60 minutes uncovered. The last 30 min increased to 400 F. Never browned. text:
I didn't read other suggestions but on my own used 1 cup splenda instead of sugar and a splash of lemon juice for the blueberry sauce. I think next time I will do 1/2 sugar 1/2 splenda. We have discount bread stores here so I used  thick slices of Texas toast. I did push all the bread down in the egg mixture to make sure it was saturated before I put it in the refrigerator. The next morning I "fluffed" it up a bit and ut it in the oven for the first 30 minutes covered. Before baking uncovered for the next 25 minutes I stirred it all up to help distribute the cream cheese better. I also sprinkled cinnamon over the top and put it back in the oven for 25 minutes. It came out wonderful!

text:
Made it for the family for Christmas Day Breakfast .... what a HIT!!  I made a few changes ... Cream cheese filing:  I whipped the cream cheese ( 1 1/2 cups) until creamy, then I added 1/4 cup heavy cream, 1/2 tsp vanilla - whipped it until it was creamy  smooth... it spread so easily.

We love fruit so I decided to changed it up a bit by adding strawberries too ....defrosted berries: 1 cup of blueberries, 1 cup of strawberries.

For the egg mixture  I added 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg 

For the berry topping: 1 cup of frozen blueberries/1 cup of strawberries defrost- keeping the juice from the defrosting.   Instead of water I used 1 cup of pomegranate juice and added the reserved juice from the defrosted fruit.  I skipped the butter and added sugar to taste.     Really I think you can use just about any kind of fruit you want .... change it up!
This is defiantly a keeper for my family on Christmas Day for breakfast!!!

It was a delightfully moist French toast and I will make it again for company coming in the New Year. The only thing I would have liked was a sauce that thoroughly covered the bread cubes. I stretched the sauce over as much of the top as possible and then let individuals add whipped cream to make sure some guests did not feel it was too much of a bread taste. I think I will monkey around with the sauce to make it cover the toast completely.

text:
As other reviewers, I made a cream cheese filling rather than just using hunks of cream cheese. I used 1.5 blocks, 1 egg and 1/2 cup powdered sugar. Were I to make again,  I would use 2 full blocks,  1 egg plus 1 egg yolk and a tad more sugar. I used a loaf of grocery store bread. It was ok but slightly soggy, but that could be because we live at altitude,  and maybe it just needed a few more minutes in the oven.   As for the sauce, the quantity recommended made only enough for a very thin layer.  I'd make 1.5 times the amount next time.

text:
I made this recipe for Christmas morning breakfast and everyone loved it.  I gave this it 4 stars because, as written, I liked the taste, and would make it again, but to love it, some modifications were needed.  1.  Made a spreadable cream cheese mixture (2 pkgs, soft cream cheese, 1/2 cup sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, enough milk to make spreadable).  2.  The blueberry sauce is too sweet, gave me a toothache.  Cut sugar in half and use flour/butter to make sauce instead of cornstarch.  I don't like the sheen cornstarch gives to food.  3.  Added 1 tsp cinnamon to egg mixture.
Thank you for sharing - it's a keeper!!!

Made for company on 12/24/17 - YUM!!  Only changes I made are to add 1/4 cup of confectioners sugar and splash of light cream to the cream cheese (used the 2 full bricks), whipped in the mixer.  Also used MORE blueberries in the casserole.  Next time I'll use the idea of loading the cream cheese into a baggie and 'piping' it onto the bread cubes.  I did use an Italian bakery loaf and let it sit out for a bit before putting all into the baking dish.  Made a double recipe of the syrup, which was really a LOT - only drizzled a bit over the casserole and then served it alongside for people to add their own.  Next time spray the  aluminum foil with cooking spray so it doesn't stick to the bread.

text:
I made this for my husband's staff meeting at work, so that they could give me feedback as I plan my holiday menu ahead for Thanksgiving and Xmas. It was a HUGE hit at my husband's work, where 15 employees gave it a thumbs up and wanted the recipe. I will definitely be added it to our holiday menus, along with a grits casserole and sausage links for a large group. Thank you for sharing! 
Here is a listing of a few minor updates I made, gathered from reading some of the feedback notes posted by others.
- I used a full loaf of Italian bread, purchased from the grocery store bakery and not on the aisle bread shelf, that I sliced and cut up with a knife.
- I used 2 (8 oz.) pkgs of cream cheese, as noted in the recipe and based on feedback of other reviewers, I creamed it with 1/4 C granulated sugar, 1 tsp vanilla extract and 1-1/2 tsp fresh lemon juice, creating a cream cheese filling and spreading it, dollop by dollop across the bread crumbs.
- I used 2 cups of fresh blueberries (4 cups total), in both instances where the recipe called for 1 cup blueberries. I also doubled the ingredient measures when making the blueberry sauce, including 1 tsp fresh lemon juice too. I spread enough of the fresh blueberry sauce across the dish, but not too much because not everyone likes as much sauce as others (I love LOTS!). I then packaged up the remaining sauce in 2 containers, 1 to be served with the dish for those who like extra sauce and the other to be stored in the refrigerator, served

Display Name:
lsiebert

city:

region:

country:

text:
It was very easy and guests took second helpings, which meant it was well liked.   It  was a cold, Wisconsin morning so the casserole was very much a comfort food.  
I almost skipped the blueberry sauce, but decided last minute to make and it was fabulous.  People used a little of that and a little maple syrup.
When I made it, as I was distributing the cream cheese, I thought one 8 oz. package was  almost enough so I only used a little bit of the second package.    Also, it calls for 1 Cup of blueberries, and to me you can never have too much fruit so I used a whole 12 oz. bag of frozen blueberries.    It really wasn't overloaded at all.  
I sprinkled some cinnamon & nutmeg on the first layers, then topped off with the remainder of bread, and finally the egg mixture.  I didn't measure the vanilla in the egg mixture, just dumped some in and I'm positive it was more than the recipe calls for.  

For the bread, I had a fresh loaf of French.  I cubed it all up and let it sit on the cutting board for a while to let it dry up a little......just did other things in the kitchen and came back to it later.  I  don't like soggy things so I figured this would help, and it did.  
Good recipe, easy to tweak to suit your individual taste.

text:
Absolutely delicious with a few tweaks. I used Italian bread as suggested in other reviews. I sprinkled each layer of bread with cinnamon and added cinnamon and a dusting of powdered sugar to coat blueberries. I added 1/4 c of the milk to cream cheese along with 1/4 c powdered sugar to sweeten a bit. I only used 1 3/4 c milk in egg mixture. This was a real hit with everyone!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7260209.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was not bad, but I would not make it again without several changes. The blueberries could probably be doubled, and the cream cheese halved. I assumed that the cream cheese, which was supposed to be cut into 1" chunks, would melt and spread. It did not; it stayed in salty little chunks. Next time I would add sugar and an egg to one 8 oz. package of softened cream cheese to make a cheesecake-like mixture, which I would drop by spoonfuls onto the bread layer. That would solve the salty little chunks matter. I also think that it could use some cinnamon or freshly grated nutmeg and lemon zest, since it was overall pretty bland and eggy. (I'll probably use 8 instead of 12 eggs too.) The blueberry sauce did not have a lot of flavor--just kind of a bland sweet without a lot of berry flavor (and I had picked the blueberries fresh--they WERE good.). I will either add more blueberries, or some lemon juice to brighten the flavor, or something--needs help though. The ingredients are good together, but I will really tweak the proportions next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fast becoming a special occasion / holiday favorite.  I will tell you that making it exactly as stated the first time out is probably a good idea!  Get a feel for the dish.  These are some things we have done and tweaked along the way.  I used some else's tip to freeze the cheese before I cut it. Amazing tip!  We have used Texas toast bread and French bread depending on what we have or sales, because thicker cut is best here.  A tiny bit of cinnamon with blueberries is never wrong!  We sometimes cut the cheese back by a half of one block,  but not more than that because one block in this huge dish isn't enough. And I always double the berries in the dish.  Seriously, if you have to ask why,  I'm not eating breakfast with you. And please, for the love, please use real maple syrup. That all being said,  this is an amazing recipe. Yes it is rich and not at all cheap to make,  but it's worth it those times when memories are being made around the food we eat.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4307143.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I listened to other reviewers and adjusted this recipe a bit.  I used Italian bread instead of day old bread with crust (as a reviewer suggested).  I also whipped 1 1/2 bricks cream cheese w/ 1/4 cup confectioners sugar and spread it over the cubed bread. I used frozen blueberries (thawed) and only 10 eggs (as a viewer suggested).  I found that I could have used a bit less egg when baked as it was a bit 'mushy'.  I had frozen blueberries that were picked by hand during the summer frozen, so those worked well.  I omitted the juice from said blueberries in fear that it would add too much liquid to the mix.  I will be making this again; however trying 8 eggs instead of 10.  I made this for Christmas morning and it was incredible.  However, I have a daughter who wouldn't eat it because of the wetness of the final product.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fell in love at first sight with this recipe!  Read  the reviews and incorporated some of the suggestions when I made it: Added 1/4 c of milk and 1/ c of confectioner's sugar to cream cheese and stirred it over a low heat long enough to become a pouring consistency. There was a small amount of syrup left over in the bottle and I added it to the blueberry syrup rather than throw it away. Sprinkled an extra 1/2 c of blueberries on top of the French toast before baking it. I did reserve the syrup and served with both blueberry and maple syrup, as someone suggested, but I won't do that again. The blueberry syrup is the  crowning touch on this recipe.  The two batches I made were consumed by 18 people. Served it with 4 lbs of bacon, but guests would have eaten more if I'd had it.

I have made this three times and each time it was a winner.I did modify the recipe a bit.  I used day old french bread but cut off the crust. It takes about 18 c. of cubed bread. Made it for the first time and I followed other recommendations when it comes to cream cheese. I whipped it instead with 3/4 c confectioner's sugar and a little bit of milk then spread it on top of the bread before putting on the bluberries, and since I used 2  8oz cream cheese, I have some left overs, so I pread it on top after adding the layer of bread and then top it with bluberries before baking it. Also I don't have any maple syrup, so I used honey instead, came out very good. I also cut down the sugar on the syrup, instead of 1 c, I used 3/4 C, not too sweet. Overall, very good! Will make this again.

text:
I made this recipe almost exactly as written.  I did use French bread, and would agree with everyone else that a "stiff" bread (unlike a regular loaf of bread) is the way to go with this recipe. The only changes I made were 1) I added cinnamon to the egg mixture 2)I sprinkled some cinnamon on top of each of the 2 bread layers 3)I poured a little of the egg mixture over the first layer of bread, but most of it went over the top layer as directed.  I did not add any sugar to the cream cheese, and it definitely didn't need any! The syrup is plenty sweet on its own. My husband and I made this together, we both loved it, we will definitely make it again!!

madhatter

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/285781.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making "overnight" French toast for years. The secret is two fold, hearty bread left overnight to firm up & custard made the night before. also, both grilling the toast and baking it as well. This recipe's ingredients work, but the cooking is different than mine. I set the bread on a cooling rack, make the custard & refrigerate overnight. I the morning,  dip the "stale" bread in the mixture 30 sec. on each side, set on cooling rack. Then, add to a medium heated pan, flip when done, add butter to both sides &  place on cookie sheet pan & place in 350 oven for 10 minutes.  Add your cream cheese & filling,  dust the outside with powdered sugar & cinnamon if desired.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is not the best as stated because it has way too much sugar.
I did use the stated no. of eggs and I did use 2% milk instead of whole milk.
I added only one quarter cup of pure cane sugar to the cream cheese, beat it til smooth and spread it on the blueberries.
My blueberry sauce is incredibly fresh tasting and not loaded with sugar.
I use fresh blueberries, add lemon juice and only enough pure cane sugar to make it slightly sweet but tart.  I add about 2 Tbsp cornstarch for 3 cups of blueberries.
The amount of sugar people use for fruit sauces and/or desserts is astounding to me.  They are so incredibly and sickening sweet.  Not to mention, sugar is creating a huge population of obese Americans.
Sorry, don't mean to be so blunt but the amount of sugar people put into their recipes is gross in my opinion.
This breakfast treat with a tart, fresh  blueberry sauce on the side is fabulous.
Fresh i s the key.  If you don't have fresh blueberries, make something else.

text:
No.  This recipe is seriously lacking.  First of all, it's ridiculously enormous.  Half this recipe will feed at least 6 people.  Secondly, it is lacking one key ingredient necessary for French Toast... CINNAMON.  I had to add cinnamon  - before, during, after...  Thirdly, TOO MUCH SUGAR!  Just yucko.  On the blueberry compote, you could use 1/4 the sugar and twice the blueberries and 2 tsp. of lemon juice.  I had to add at least 1/2 cup of lemon juice to cut the horrid sweetness and give it some actual flavor!  This recipe would be better served without the cream cheese and skip the compote altogether and use syrup when served.  If you have taste buds, this recipe will be seriously disappointing to you.

city:

country:
None
text:
With a couple of the changes I read in the reviews, this is 100% a keeper. I creamed the cream cheese (12 oz not 16) then put it in a zip lock bag, snipped the tip and swirled it on the bread cubes.  I used 2 cups of berries in the bread and 1 cup in the syrup.  My large eggs weren't very large but I used 11, added a dash of lemon juice and cinnamon  to the egg mixture because I'd forgotten to sprinkle over the bread :) it really was quite easy to put together as I'd printed out the recipe and made my changes on paper. I also used my plastic 9x13 pan lid so I could occasionally flip my  mixture a couple of times to disperse the egg mixture to the top layer of bread cubes.  Little extra things made a huge difference.

text:
After reading the many reviews, I decided to make this. It was just ok.  Turned out a little soggy but I did cream the cream cheese with powdered sugar so it would be spreadable but probably added a little too much milk while whipping it. Maybe try heavy cream instead of milk. I'm glad that I took the suggestions of others and added the powdered sugar to the cream cheese and cut it in half. I also added cinnamon to the egg mixture.  Needed a lot more. I also doubled the blueberries. It was kind of tasteless to me but smelled nice while cooking. The blueberry syrup on the stove was a whole other story. Delicious!  Can use that on anything. I normally don't make changes to these recipes based on the reviews because after all, a recipe is a recipe for a reason.  I'm glad that I read the reviews but not sure that I would make this again.

text:
So I made this before reading the top comments. I split the recipe in half because I just made it for me and my husband. I used regular wheat bread, and I should have used French bread because my version based on the original recipe was too soggy in the middle. Also, I cut up the cream cheese into the one inch cubes and layered them. However, they still didn't seem to bake into the bread mixture; they were still chunky. So next time I'm going to let the cream cheese soften a bit and then spread it onto the bread layers. It does need more blueberries. The blueberry compote mixture made on the stove turned out great. I'll make some changes next time I make this.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5876003.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very yummy. Everyone said it was like eating blueberry pie for breakfast. So obviously it's quite sweet. I followed the advice of others and added powdered sugar to the cream cheese-probably a big reason for the sweetness. If you don't want it as sweet then follow the original recipe with no powdered sugar added. One person used only 10 eggs so I did 11 eggs which is completely sufficient. And I definitely agree that a hearty crusty bread has to be used, otherwise a regular sandwich bread would pretty much disintegrate. Side note: when I made this it was for Mother's Day brunch and there were only 5 of us. Because of the rest of the brunch menu and because of the sweetness,  each person had only one serving of this so there was quite a bit of leftovers. I've put it in the freezer and we'll find out later if it'll be the same when I take it out to finish off for the next event.

Enjoyed the final product with many revisions based on previous reviews. Decrease eggs. Use sturdy bread. Decrease sugar in blueberry syrup. sheila

city:

country:

text:
I've made this a few times now, and of course I changed it.  I always do, mostly because I have to use what's on hand. Im not running out to the store just to get that one item I didnt have in the house... like blueberries. But I did have peaches, canned, then well drained and mashed a bit with a ricer.  Then of course, I looked at the cream cheese... nope, no way was cream cheese going to work with peaches. Soooo - I opted for some whipping (heavy) cream. and with a bit of peach syrup left over from the can that i saved from the night before....  but i didnt want it so .. well eggy.. so i decreased the eggs.. I also noted my bread wasnt really dry enough even though it was two day old - so the liquid helped there..I ended up using 8 eggs.. , but I think you'd have to check the dryness and the  consistency of your bread after adding the egg and cream... and make up your own mind on how many to use.. cinnamon and brown sugar for the peaches of course and it was good to go in the fridge.  In the morning,
I noticed that the eggs kind of pooled a bit at the bottom....  I thought that might create a kind of layer of egg... so I flipped it into a new pan and let it sit out while i got the oven going, the coffee going, the bacon frying... and then i made  peach sauce :) brown sugar, so used less, and less cornstarch, water with a bit of the peach syrup... Im looking forward to trying it with blueberries.. think I'll skip the cream cheese entirely - 
What a wonderful breakfast idea,

text:
I used half cinnamon, raisin bread, the one with powered sugar topping and half polish rye bread (left over breads) and only one package of cream cheese and fresh berries.  Friday evening layered bread, cream cheese and berries.  Mixed egg etc together in a separate covered container, refrigerated both. Saturday night poured egg mixture over bread, recovered.  Took out of refrig half hour to warm, then baked and served Sunday morning.  Delicious!!  Great ! make ahead recipe.

country:
None
text:
I make this every time I need to bring something for a brunch and on holidays.  I did find a way to make applying the cream cheese less irritating/messy.  I got a squeeze bottle ( the old style ketchup ones from the 70's) and with softened cream cheese put it in the bottle, cut the tip to make it wider, and was able to put the cream cheese on much easier, better coverage, less mess, it was a joy.  Just make sure the cream cheese is softened.  Tap bottle upside down to get more at the top for better use.

text:
I made this with fresh strawberries. I followed advice of others and decreased the eggs to 10, thinned cream cheese with a little milk and added a bit of powdered sugar. I spread the cream cheese on slices of challah bread, then cubed. My berries were sweet so when I made the syrup I didn't add maple syrup. This recipe is good but my guests enjoyed the edges and corners the most and the center was firm but still a little soggy. Next time I think I will mix the base up as directed and then bake the mixture in muffin tins to give it more crunch.

text:
This is a wonderful breakfast casserole for brunch or for a special occasion. For two people, I halved the recipe for the French Toast, but made a full recipe for the sauce. The only changes made were (1) I used slightly less cream cheese than called for, and (2) I added a small amount of cinnamon and nutmeg to the egg mixture before pouring over the bread cubes. I will make this again, probably many times. It's sweet, but oh so good! If you are making the full recipe, I highly recommend making a double batch of the sauce. It would be wonderful over vanilla ice cream if you have leftovers!

text:
Karan1946, thank you for sharing this recipe.  I have made this recipe numerous times, the family loves it. Changes made: did not add the blueberry sauce on top, as suggested (too sweet for my family). Used hearty whole wheat bread, cubed and left out  24 hours (before assembling ingredients). Increased(frozen) blueberries to 2 cups. Substituted 8 oz of feta for the cream cheese. Generous amount of cinnamon. While baking: cover for 45 minutes,  uncover for 15 minutes.

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for Christmas morning and was almost in tears - at 1 hour of baking the egg-milk mixture was still liquid, had not begun to cook into custard texture. But 40 minutes later, it was perfect. I made this recipe following directions almost exactly. Changes I made - used multigrain crusty loaf, a fairly dense bread. Add some nutmeg and cinnamon to the egg-milk mixture. Only used 8 oz cream cheese, which was plenty. I used Stonewall Kitchen's Blueberry syrup instead of making it myself - don't need even more work on Christmas morning. Changes I would make in the future - more blueberries in the center. Cut the cream cheese into smaller pieces - 1 inch is too big and creates a lump in the middle and no cream cheese flavor in other parts. Recipe itself as given needs work, but overall was a big success. Just allow extra baking time just in case.

text:
Made this exactly as the recipe states, using a round of Italian bread I had that needed to be used. I like to follow each recipe before making changes. It is delicious. My entire family enjoyed it Thanksgiving morning. It's been requested for Christmas morning. Read the previous reviews and made notes when deciding to make this one. I'm guessing it will be even more delicious with a little less cream cheese (unless you and yours love cream cheese) and some confectioners sugar mixed into the cream cheese as another reviewer suggested. It is so good as is that I can imagine it is out of this world with that change.
I have guests who ate seconds and asked for the recipe. Thank you for sharing this.

I sprinkled cinnamon and sugar over the layer and on top and used sugar instead of any maple syrup in the egg mixture.

userID:
7279921
Display Name:
PT
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Would definitely make again!  

Followed a few tips from others...and I'm glad I did.  Have had to be gluten free for over 20 years now.  Finding good French or Italian bread is hard and pricey, so I used a regular loaf of gluten-free white bread.  Cubed it and felt the dozen eggs would be too much.  Dropped eggs down to ten and only used about nine.  Also reduced milk accordingly.  When I started to compose the dish, my concern was that due to bread selection a baking pan would be too big so I grabbed my covered casserole dish and carefully put it together.  Only used 1 and 1/3 box of cream cheese cubed small which I thought was plenty.  Added the nutmeg and cinnamon to the top per the suggestion of another reviewer.  May mix it in next time.  Allowed another ten minutes  for baking d/t the density.  Turned out beautiful!  Proofed up like a souffle', which tasted like  an awesome, decadent French toast.  Great for presentation.  When I went in to take off the cover after the first 30 minutes it had already proofed up, lifting the cover right up.  

Sauce, eh, I've had and made better.  Didn't care for the addition of corn starch. Also added the fresh lemon juice, which gave it some life.

Will definitely be making this again.  A great presentation dish that will wow your guests. ..a great dish when you want to have a nice breakfast that doesn't tie you up all morning...love make-ahead dishes like this!  

Try it, you won't be disappointed!

text:
This was a HUGE success at my breakfast party this morning! I did make a few very minor changes from the recipe. I used an Italian loaf of bread, diced and toasted. I took note of the reviews complaining about huge chunks of cream cheese, so I cut one 8 oz. pkg into a very small dice and sprinkled that around.  I doubled the amount of blueberries both in the bread mixture and in the sauce. I cut the amount of water in the sauce to 1/2 c and added 1 teaspoon of lemon juice to the sauce. If I ever need a blueberry sauce/syrup, this will be my "go to" recipe. I did not pour any of the sauce over the bake but served it separately in a bowl. The bake and the sauce looked yummy! I can't wait to make this again! Thank you!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read all the reviews prior and the main complaint was inconsistent moisture issues - some say too dry and others too mushy. The key is to make sure the lower level of the bread is somewhat stale, dry or slightly cooked so that the layers do not become an off -putting mush. That and of course cooking it long enough. As far as the dryness, I altered the recipe by increasing the cream cheese mixture by an additional 1/2, and I created a brown sugar and cinnamon glaze for the top using 1/2 stick of butter (melted), and eyeballed the brown sugar to add just enough just keep as a viscous liquid without the presence of butter, and added cinnamon to taste.  It turned out great. Good luck.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this three times and it is excellent. I used a loaf of Italian bread that I cubed myself. Would be nice to know a total number  cups bread, rather than slices. I think the loaf was more bread than the original recipe proportions so I pressed down the bread before adding the egg mixture to help with everything soaking up the bread and also helps to make it easier to cut.  I also used more than 2 cups total blueberries - doubled to 2 cups layered in the casserole and doubled to 2 cups in the sauce. Seems this would be dry and with much less flavor with any less blueberries (but I also likely used more bread). I softened the cream cheese and beat with about 2 tablespoons of milk so I could make it more of a spread across the bottom layer (otherwise the cream cheese will never quite melt and mix into all of the servings). I sprinkled cinnamon across the middle cream cheese/blueberry layer. And finally added about a tablespoon of fresh lemon juice to the syrup.

I wish I had made the following changes (others said the same, but I never like changing anything before making the recipe "as is" first. I would've either skipped cream cheese or tried freezing/grating it because the blobs did not melt/mix and were therefore unappetizing.
I also wouldn't poured the blueberry syrup over everything  - instead I would serve on the side. Once those eggs turn blueberry-purple, it's not nearly as attractive/appetizing (looks kinda gross, actually). Overall the taste was pretty good but not outstanding (mixed-in cream cheese might've helped).

Yum, Yum, Yummy!  Made this for 4th of July holiday weekend. Turned out perfect. I followed other reviewers suggestions and added some powered sugar to the cream cheese along with a little milk to make the cream cheese more spreadable. Spread that onto french bread slices and made "sandwiches" which I then cut up into cubes. Layered half my cubes, fresh  blueberries then the remaining cubes. Topped with the egg mixture and refrigerated overnight.  Cooked as directed. Perfect amount of sweetness for my families taste buds.

text:
For my first attempt, I made it exactly as directed, and I'm confident it turned out like it was supposed to,  a French Toast custard casserole. Unlike other reviewers, I would not reduce the egg, but I used an entire day old sourdough loaf, so I had plenty of bread to soak up egg. I would, however, consider creaming, instead of cubing, the cream cheese, as some folks suggested, for better distribution. I probably wouldn't add sugar, in fact, I would probably omit the maple syrup next time, because it didn't sweeten it up, and I prefer adding syrup or jam after it comes out of the oven. Mmmm.

text:
I'm giving this recipe 5 stars even though I varied a little from the recipe.  I used less cream cheese and mixed it with a little milk and icing sugar to spread over the bread cubes.  Next time I might do as another reviewer did and that's to put the cream cheese in with the eggs, etc and pour it altogether over the all the bread cubes rather than layering it.  I also had to add thin down the syrup with a little water, maybe half a cup actually.  Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly.  I whole-heartedly recommend this to anyone.  Delicious.   Some of my guests had seconds at brunch this morning. It's great being able to prepare it the day before.  Would make a great dessert anytime.

Thanks! I'm sure it will become a tradition!

11364797
Display Name:
Stacy Meyer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2796089.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a signature Sunday breakfast dish from a small local diner.  The owner was generous enough to share the recipe with the public, and it is WELL worth the effort.  However I have a few strongly-suggest tweaks.  First, use more blueberries!  Two cups is about perfect.  Also, I use only one brick of cream cheese, and just pinch it into much smaller pieces than shown in the video (more like a quarter to a half inch).  That way, you get the flavor and richness, without getting a whole mouthful of what tastes like molten chalk.   I also give the top of the casserole a light brush of melted butter after removing the foil for the second half of the baking time.   That adds great color, crispness, and richness to the top crust.  And finally, the blueberry sauce needs a LOT of work from what's shown here.   First, add the cup of blueberries at the start, so they can cook in with the sugar, water, and cornstarch, to release their juice (aka, flavor!).   Then add a second cup of berries at the end, after the sauce has thickened.  For brighter berry flavor, I also suggest putting a tablespoon of lemon juice into the measuring cup before filling the rest of the way with water,  A scant pinch of salt helps too.   Those tweaks help elevate this dish from "pretty good," to absolutely fantastic!  It's been our go-to for a special occasion breakfast for years.

I have made this twice now. It is very easy to make, feeds a large party of people and most of the work you can do the night before which is what I prefer to do so I am not trying to entertain and cook at the same time. The second time I made it I used 2x the amount of blueberries vs what the recipe called for. My brother and I love blueberries and you can't have too many. It is sweet so not for everyone. I served it with bacon and scrambled eggs for those with not a sweet tooth. I will definitely continue to make this for special breakfast parties/holidays.

text:
This was a delicious recipe!  I give it 4.5 stars overall.  I love these types of casseroles that can be made the day before so there is minimal work the next morning.  With that being said, I didn't prepare ahead of time for this, so I made it the morning of.  Overall I went by the recipe except a few changes.  I only made half since it was just two of us.  I cut down one of the eggs(5 eggs to half the recipe) and needed to still bake a few minutes extra since it was very liquid-y still after baking an hour.  With these types of casseroles, I add in some sugar to the egg/milk mixture because I like it a bit sweeter.  I also double the maple syrup.  Instead of cubing the cream cheese, I soften in the microwave and spread it over top of the bread cubes.  The blueberry syrup for the end was delicious and for my tastes I added more sugar as well with a splash of vanilla.  The blueberry syrup is delicious and great to make to serve with pancakes, waffles, etc!  Overall this is something that I will definitely make again.  We really enjoyed it!  Thanks for the recipe!!

text:
I made this recipe for blueberry and strawberry this morning and both flavors got rave reviews from my brunch guests. I used Texas toast and added 2 more eggs to the egg mixture to compensate for the extra bread and made sure to push down the entire bread and fruit mix in to the egg mixture before placing in the fridge overnight. Based on other reviewers feedback, I spread the cream cheese on to the bread before cutting and placing in to the pan, the cream cheese was consistent throughout the dish, rather than globs here and there. I did make extra sauce for the French toast, one blueberry and one strawberry. It was a great dish to go alongside the vegetable frittata and mimosas that were served. I will be making this again.

text:
Made this recipe for a brunch at our community.  It was delicious!!  I should have read the reviews first, though, because I made the recipe as is & had to tweek it at the end.  The middle was not done, even after I had raised the temp by a few degrees & cooked it longer.  I took it out, mixed it with a spatula, and cooked it an extra 10-15 min.  By doing this, the cream cheese was spread throughout!  I made the blueberry syrup & poured it over the top when it was done.  I love the fact that most of the work is done the night before.  I will definitely make this again, when we have out of town guests,  so I can visit with them instead of standing over the stove making breakfast!

text:
I made this for Christmas morning brunch.  I was never much of a cook until I became a stay at home mom and wife.  In the year and a half since my cooking skills have grown significantly. However, my mother-in-law always found a way to politely decline anything I cooked.  We agreed to do Christmas morning at our house this year instead of moving two small children to her house.  I made this, hopefully to impress, and it pulled through with rave reviews! Even other family members were asking for the recipe at our extended family get together that night.  This was voted the official Christmas morning dish, and...my mother-in-law now never turns down to try my dishes!

The cream cheese didn't melt as much as I would have liked, but it was still delicious!  I coupled it with smoked sausage, eggs, and baked red potatoes with sliced red peppers.  The sweet and savoring went very well together.

I made this New Year's Day morning and it was a hit - soooo good!! 

I made two changes, and I've seen these mentioned in other reviews: I used a whole loaf of French bread rather than regular sandwich bread so it would hold up to the weight of everything else, and I used thawed frozen blueberries instead of fresh - which gave it an extra blueberry punch with the juice.

text:
Used a whole loaf of Italian bread, cubed.  Used 2 C. blueberries for filling.  Creamed 1 1/2 pkgs. cream cheese, enough milk to make it more speadable and a small amt. of xx sugar.  I put the cream cheese mixture in a baggie and cut off the corner and piped it over the 1st layer of bread, then took a knife and spread it around a little more.  Used 1 c. skim milk, 1 C. fat free 1/2 & 1/2.  . I added the syrup but could probably leave out.  Only used 9 eggs, no problem.  I cut back on the sugar slightly also.  After pouring milk over top and to take my hands and push bread down so it was all soaked by the milk.   Everyone liked it.

text:
I thought this was more of a dessert than a breakfast dish. I will make it again because it was delish. I took the advise of some blended comments. I used Italian bread an left the crust on.  I soaked the bread in the egg mixture (only used 10 eggs)  to make sure all the bread got some because I also blended the cream cheese with some sugar and spread it over the first layer. (it was a little hard to spread but with patience not impossible) I felt that the eggs wouldn't have soaked through the solid spread of cream cheese and that's why I soaked the bread first. I used more blueberries as well, enough to cover the dish because well...who doesn't like more blueberries. I also served the topping on the side rather than over the dish this way people could use more or less according to their liking. It was a hit!!!

text:
I made this for breakfast Christmas morning. It was delicious and everyone loved it.  I too made a few adjustments after reading the reviews.
I used 1 1/2 blocks cream cheese, added a splash of milk,  1/4 cup of confectioners sugar and small splash of vanilla and beat till blended.
I dropped small dollops on top of the bread pieces (I used Texas Toast bread) and was  able to spread it pretty well. I started with nine eggs but needed more.  I cooked it a little longer than the 1 hour. Would  highly recommend this .

text:
I made this for Christmas morning breakfast.
We thought it was very good.
I did make a couple of changes after reading other reviews.
-used 12 oz. of cream cheese, mixed it with 1/4 powdered sugar & some vanilla 
-used 2 cups of blueberries in the dish
-the sauce I used 2 cups of blueberries, 1 1/2 cups of water & 2 Tbsp of butter - other ingredients stayed the same amounts
-added cinnamon to both the egg mixture & sauce 
We will have this again!  It it very easy to make the day before & just stick it in the oven the next morning.

city:

country:
None
text:
This has become an expected contribution at my family annual Christmas breakfast.  This year I used Strawberries with a touch of lemon zest.  It was fabulous!  Here are a couple of my additions/changes to a great recipe.  I used Texas Toast instead of regular bread.  I saw the idea of adding french bread, but honestly, I found it to be a little heavy and more like bread pudding.  The Texas toast seemed to be a great choice.   I also added a 2 tablespoons of sugar to the egg mixture, since it is like french toast batter, I do the same for my regular French toast.  When you add the berries and syrup at the end it really is already sugary, I don't like things overly sweet or it would just become a dessert instead of something for breakfast.  All and all, this is a great recipe and after you make it a couple of times then you can expand it to suit your tastes.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  We've made it two years in a row for a large family holiday gathering (feeds 12 people, as long as you're feeding them other things too) and it's a crowd favorite. The first year we made it exactly as written and thought it might have had a little too much cream cheese; we used about 1 1/3- 1 1/2 this year instead of two full bricks. It's only a slight change, but was delicious and brought out the other flavors versus having a lot of cream cheese in every bite. We also use an Italian crusty bread. Yum!!

Made half a recipe in an 8x8 pyrex.  Made according to directions except had a little less than 8oz cream cheese.  Used 2 spoons on room-temp cream cheese to drop it onto bread (not cubed), like dropping cookie dough.  Used sliced sheepherder's bread from Costco.  Didn't use all the syrup.  Delicious and rich as written; good contrast between creamy, fluffy, and sweet.  I wouldn't make any changes next time (also tried with cinnamon and would not use again).

text:
Didn't have all of the cream cheese so I used marscapone with just a touch of cream cheese.  Added powdered sugar to it and stirred until soft so it spread easily over the layer of bread cubes.  Added cinnamon to the egg mixture.  Like other suggested, added lemon juice to the blueberry sauce mixture to cut the sweetness a little.  It was a hit - will definitely be making this again.

text:
I made this recipe two times during the holidays. Great recipe. I did made some changes as suggested by other reviewers. I used Townsend frozen blueberries from Sam's club and thawed into strainer then when making the sauce, added it back in. I doubled the sauce. One for the table for extra yummy topping. I also divided up the cream cheese. Layering bread, cream cheese, blueberries and then again. In the winter I would suggest taking it out of the refrigerator a little longer and make sure oven is fully preheated.
.... .Perfect!!

text:
We loved it!  I am one of those people who doesn't quite have the ingredients on hand so I either omit or sub for ingredients.  In this case, I did not have any vanilla extract but since it is mostly for flavoring I was willing to forgo it since the other ingredients compensate.  I also modified the sugar/fat content by reducing the sugar and cream cheese amount.   Also, could not let it sit overnight in the refrig.  Instead, I mixed all the ingredients together in a blender (cream cheese too and add milk to make it a bit more runny if needed).   Took the bread cubes (I used brioche) toss it all in together with the blue berries and popped it in my oven proof container and baked.

userID:
1016363
Display Name:
1JOHN513
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very delicious!! I made the following changes based on reviews. I mixed 1/4 c powdered sugar into about 12 oz of cream cheese, I increased the blueberries to 2 cups. 12 slices of bread was not enough (even though it was oversized sheepherders), so I cubed up the rest of the loaf and toasted it in the oven. Well, I got distracted and they ended up a cross between stale cubes and croutons, but I used them anyway, and you could not tell! This was very good. HOWEVER, I think you need to be careful with the quantity of sugar. Our blueberries weren't very sweet, so if you ate the casserole w/o any syrup, it was perfect, as far as sweetness goes. However, if you poured on the very, very sweet blueberry syrup, it was too sweet for everyone except for the kids! Edible, but sweet. When I make it again, I will NOT add sugar to the cream cheese, and I will use just 8 oz. It was a whole lot of cream cheese in the middle....about the thickness of a thick layer of frosting in the middle of the cake. For our family, just a little too gooey/rich. Bottom line...my advice, follow the recipe as written except decrease the cream cheese to just one pkg., unless you want a thick layer of cheese. You may need to increase your bread cubes, and you may consider decreasing the sugar in the syrup, depending on how sweet the blueberries are....the syrup is excellent, but VERY sweet.

text:
Turned out well, though a little soggy at the bottom. Might cut back on some of the milk or eggs next time.  I used a brioche loaf of bread, which had a nice buttery flavor. I added more blueberries to the dish and doubled the sauce, though I don't think the extra sauce was necessary for the dish.  Added about a tsp of cinnamon & nutmeg and a dash of cardamom to the egg mixture.  Also added a tablespoon of lemon juice to the doubled syrup, and cut back on the sugar by 1/2 cup.  Next time I will either cut the cream cheese up smaller or spread it out over the bread more -- it just stayed in big chunks instead of melting like I thought it would. Overall, though, it was good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a five star recipe if you add 1/4 cup powdered sugar to the cream cheese and sprinkle with cinnamon. Otherwise I made exactly as written. Just drop by teaspoonfuls on top of first bread layer. All French toast has cinnamon on it so that was a given for me. Used two small containers of blueberries. Put one cup on top of cheese. The rest (and I didn't even measure) I used in the syrup. 12 eggs. Real maple syrup. I pressed the top layer of bread down in the egg mixture so it all got covered. Baked in a convection oven at 350* for 30 minutes covered and 30 minutes uncovered. This timing came out perfect for my oven. Poured some of the syrup over the casserole while warm. Served the rest on the table for those who wanted more. Served with skinless smoked sausage for an awesome breakfast. This could be put together real fast in the evening if the bread was already cubed and the cream cheese mixed. I used about 16, 1/2" slices of store bakery French bread cubed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a total hit for our Christmas brunch! I actually didn't expect the kids to like it because they aren't big on blueberries--but they came back for seconds. Used thawed, fresh Maine blueberries (which I'd frozen myself)...so much better than the big grocery blueberries--if you can get them, use them!  (Wyman's frozen blueberries are also Maine berries, if you can't get them fresh yourself.) I did take some of the suggestions of others and reduced to 10 eggs, dusted with cinnamon and fresh grated nutmeg before refrigerating, and whipped the cream cheese with a tiny bit of milk and about 1/4 c. of powdered sugar so it would spread a little easier. Definitely need to press the bread into the liquid mix before letting it sit overnight, so it gets well sopped up. Served the syrup on the side, but it's definitely what makes this dish special, so don't forgo it altogether! This will stay on our rotation for a long, long time!

text:
This is the second time I've tried a French toast casserole and both have been too soggy in the middle! I've read that some people prefer these to be the texture of bread pudding, but I would like mine to be more firm. Not sure what I'm doing wrong, maybe it's the bread? I used sourdough this time because it's all I could find. Anyway, flavor was good but I personally feel it was way too much cream cheese. I agree with others that should be cut in half. Also less egg and it definitely needs cinnamon and more maple syrup. The cream cheese needs a different solution too. I like the idea of creaming it first like others  mentioned so you don't get big chunks of cream cheese. Good idea but this recipe needs some work.

text:
The only reason I'm giving four stars and not five is the lengthy bake time. Pretty much became brunch instead of breakfast!! It was pretty good though. Better than I thought it would be. I cut the recipe in half for 2 adults and my three year old daughter(who actually ate it and even said it was good)! Hubby liked it and was busted attacking it with a fork later that night!!! I did alter recipe a tiny bit just by adding pecans that toasted up nice in the oven and made blueberry sauce not as sweet by adding 1/4 cup less sugar, a couple squirts of lemon juice and little cinnamon. I also used a little bit less cream cheese and cut it into smaller chunks.  I would like to make this again for a special occasion breakfast or brunch. Good one for something like that.
